items.title: What we know about the suspected murder-suicide of a Perth family of four
items.description: An entire family has been found dead in their own home — a mother, a father and their two teenage boys, with police describing the event as "highly distressing" and a "devastating tragedy".

items.title: Gemini telescope reveals comet ATLAS crumbling after solar pass

featured_image.name: Comet C/2025 K1 (ATLAS) crumbles apart in stunning new ...

items.description:
Astronomers this week released new images documenting two distinct celestial objects bearing the ATLAS name: one a solar system comet that fragmented after its close solar approach, and the other an interstellar visitor that continues to puzzle scientists with its unusual jet structures and delayed detection in archival data.

The Gemini North telescope in Hawaii captured high-resolution footage of Comet C/2025 K1 (ATLAS) breaking apart, with images released Thursday showing the comet's nucleus splintering into multiple fragments following its closest approach to the Sun on October 8, 2025. Meanwhile, NASA confirmed that the interstellar object 3I/ATLAS had been present in archived TESS satellite data from May 2025—nearly two months before its official discovery on July 1, 2025.[1][2]

items.title: Five quick hits: 'Old man' Djokovic turns back time and cramping Carlos causes controversy
items.description: Gadecki and Peers make their own bit of history and "old man" Djokovic turns back the clock to reach his 11th Aussie final. Here are the quick hits from day 13 at the Australian Open.

items.title: Oil prices ease as Trump signals openness to Iran talks

featured_image.name: Oil prices surge 3% to five-month high on worries US could ...

items.description:
Crude oil prices retreated from multi-month highs on Friday after President Donald Trump signaled he was open to talks with Iran over its nuclear program, tempering fears of an imminent military strike that had driven a sharp rally earlier in the week.

Brent crude fell nearly 1% on Friday, pulling back from the $70 level it had breached the day before for the first time since July, according to CNBC. West Texas Intermediate also declined more than 1%, dropping from the four-month highs reached Thursday.[1][2]

"President Trump's readiness to consider diplomacy with Iran appears to make a U.S. military action less probable than it was yesterday," said Tamas Varga, an analyst at PVM Oil Associates.[2]

items.title: Putin envoy to meet Trump officials in Miami Saturday

featured_image.name: Putin envoy Dmitriev to travel to Miami, meet members of ...

items.description:
Kirill Dmitriev, Russian President Vladimir Putin's special envoy, is scheduled to travel to Miami on Saturday for meetings with members of the Trump administration, according to two sources familiar with the plans, Reuters reported on Thursday.[1][2][3]

The visit marks the latest in a series of diplomatic engagements between Moscow and Washington as the two sides work toward a resolution to the war in Ukraine. Dmitriev, who heads the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF), has emerged as a central figure in the Trump administration's efforts to broker peace between Russia and Ukraine.

items.title: Catherine O'Hara from Home Alone and Schitt's Creek dies
items.description: The Canadian-born actress died at her home in Los Angeles "following a brief illness", according to a statement from her agency.

items.title: Laughing at Melania's ticket sales? You might be missing the point
items.description: Dire box office sales surrounding the US first lady's bio-doc have made headlines, but some argue there's likely a good reason Jeff Bezos's Amazon MGM Studios has splashed so much cash on MELANIA.

items.title: New electrode converts exhaust CO2 into formic acid in one step

featured_image.name: New three-layer electrode converts exhaust CO2 into formic acid

items.description:
Researchers in South Korea have developed a new electrode capable of capturing carbon dioxide directly from exhaust gases and converting it into formic acid in a single step, an advancement that could simplify industrial carbon recycling.

The study, published January 21 in ACS Energy Letters and selected as an official press release by the American Chemical Society, introduces a three-layer electrode design that functions under realistic conditions rather than requiring purified carbon dioxide.[1][2][3]

items.title: Deep in the desert a car graveyard offers a new vehicle for survival stories
items.description: The artists of Mimili, in the APY Lands of South Australia, are using new methods to share crucial knowledge of Country and culture, including repurposed car parts.

items.title: Children living in makeshift tents in Gaza are dying from hypothermia
items.description: Mohammed died from hypothermia while in his mother's arms after a cold night in Gaza. His family are one of hundreds of thousands of Gazans enduring harsh winter conditions in flimsy tents across the enclave.

items.title: Djokovic hits out at critics after epic Australian Open win over Sinner
items.description: After beating two-time defending Jannik Sinner in five gruelling sets, Novak Djokovic sets his sights on those who doubted whether he could still be an Australian Open contender.

items.title: Trump's Greenland threats halt US-Danish climate research

featured_image.name: Trump's Greenland Threats Put Crucial Climate Change ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump's escalating pressure on Greenland has begun to chill scientific ties between American and Greenlandic researchers, with at least one climate program halted and future collaborations cast into uncertainty. The diplomatic strain comes just days after the United States officially exited the Paris Agreement, further isolating the country from global climate efforts.

Ross Virginia, a professor emeritus of environmental studies at Dartmouth College, said a climate program he ran with Greenlandic colleagues was halted by "mutual agreement" due to the tensions, according to Bloomberg News. "Direct cooperation is paused while we determine what a future vision for collaborative science diplomacy — particularly involving education and younger students — could look like," he said.[1][2][3]

Another US scientist, speaking anonymously for fear of jeopardizing relationships, said some research partnerships had been affected by the political climate.[3][1]

items.title: Zelensky backs energy truce, says Ukraine will halt strikes if Russia reciprocates

featured_image.name: Zelenskiy says Russia seems more inclined now to a ceasefire ...

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky endorsed a U.S.-proposed pause on strikes targeting energy infrastructure on Friday, pledging that Kyiv would halt attacks on Russian energy facilities if Moscow reciprocates—though he emphasized that no formal agreement exists between the two nations.

"If Russia does not strike our energy infrastructure—generation facilities or any other energy assets—we will not strike theirs," Zelensky told reporters on January 30, characterizing the arrangement as "an opportunity, not an agreement."[1][2][3]

The development follows President Donald Trump's announcement Thursday that Russian President Vladimir Putin had agreed to suspend attacks on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities for one week amid extreme cold weather. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov confirmed Friday that Trump "did indeed make a personal request to President Putin to refrain from striking Kyiv for a week until February 1 in order to create favorable conditions for negotiations."[4][5][1]

items.title: NASA probe data reveals origins of solar wind heating

featured_image.name: Durable Parker Solar Probe going strong after first five years

items.description:
Using measurements from NASA's Parker Solar Probe during its record-breaking closest approach to the sun, scientists have mapped the dynamic "shell" of hot gas where the solar wind is born, shedding new light on one of the most enduring mysteries in heliophysics.

The research, led by University of Arizona associate professor Kristopher Klein and published this week in Geophysical Research Letters, offers the first detailed analysis of how energy moves through the sun's outer atmosphere at distances never before measured, with implications for predicting space weather events that affect Earth's satellites, communications systems, and power grids.[1][2][3]

items.title: Satellite images show Iran building roofs over bombed nuclear sites

featured_image.name: Satellite photos show activity at Iran nuclear sites as ...

items.description:
New satellite imagery reveals Iran is placing roofs over two nuclear facilities bombed by Israel and the United States last year, raising concerns that Tehran is attempting to shield salvage operations from outside observation as the regime continues to block international inspectors from the sites.

Images from Planet Labs PBC show that Iran completed construction of roofs over damaged buildings at its Natanz and Isfahan nuclear facilities in late December 2025 and early January 2026, according to an Associated Press report published Thursday. The activity marks the first major construction visible by satellite at any of Iran's stricken nuclear sites since Israel's 12-day war with the Islamic Republic in June 2025.[1][2]

items.title: Live: Email to former prince Andrew among millions of new 'Epstein files' documents
items.description: More than 2,000 videos and 180,000 images have been released as part of the batch, which comes weeks after a legally mandated deadline signed by Donald Trump. Follow live.

items.description: As the US president faces domestic consequences for his violent immigration crackdown, his geopolitical bluffs across the world also come at a price.

items.title: Taylor picked as Liberal right's leading man as stalking of Ley begins
items.description: One Liberal source told the ABC a challenge to Sussan Ley's leadership is now a "matter of when, not if".

items.title: Trump deploys massive US naval force as Iran nuclear deadline nears

featured_image.name: Trump tells Iran to drop nuclear aims and stop killing protesters to ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump has dispatched a substantial U.S. naval fleet to the Persian Gulf in an escalating standoff with Iran, warning Tehran on Thursday that "time is running out" to negotiate a nuclear agreement or face military action he described as "far worse" than the June 2025 strikes that targeted Iranian nuclear facilities.

The deployment, which Trump has repeatedly called a "massive Armada," is led by the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln and now includes at least six guided-missile destroyers in the region, with the USS Delbert D. Black crossing into the Red Sea on January 29 and docking at Israel's port of Eilat on Friday. The carrier strike group entered the Middle East region on January 26 after departing the South China Sea earlier this month.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Trump says he's in talks with Iran as US warships mass in Gulf

featured_image.name: Daily Life In Tehran And Anti-U.S. Billboard

items.description:
President Donald Trump has confirmed he is in talks with Iranian leaders while deploying a major naval fleet to the Persian Gulf, escalating pressure on Tehran to accept U.S. demands on its nuclear program or face military action he warns will be "far worse" than last year's strikes.

"I have had, and I am planning on it," Trump said Friday when asked about recent conversations with Iran, adding that he conveyed two conditions: "No nukes. And two, stop killing protesters." Ten U.S. warships, including the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln and six guided-missile destroyers, are now positioned within striking range of Iran, according to U.S. Navy officials.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
